I am a 27 year old man with a Bachelor of Science degree in Psychology with minors in Biology and Chemistry. I'd like to share my personal opinion regarding the DEA proposal on kratom.
I oppose the DEA's proposal to put alkaloids found in kratom on the list of banned schedule 1 controlled substances. 
I started using kratom tea 3 years ago. Today I feel that this is an herb that helped me lead a better life. I have issues with pain and chronic fatigue and at times find it hard to have energy to work and lead a good, productive life. Most people drink coffee for energy, but I find coffee to be too strong - it makes me too stimulated and anxious. Kratom, however, feels milder and helps me get through the day started without all that. 
I also found that it helps my pain without side effects that I experience with OTC NSAIDs. As for scheduled prescription drugs, I've been prescribed opioids for impacted wisdom teeth and they were very strong. They had some side effects: they clouded my mind and had a powerful effect on my body. Kratom, on the other hand, doesn't feel to me like that drug, it's rather like a mild herbal tea that helps me feel  better without a strong effect on my body and without the above mentioned side effects. It doesn't at all feel to me like a scheduled medication, I'd rather compare it to helpful unscheduled herbs like ginseng, valerian root, ashwagandha and other such common supplements.
When I took a full blood check and physical after using kratom regularly for about 2 years, my lab results were quite healthy.
I find DEA's proposal to label kratom as a schedule 1 substance to be unfounded by evidence. DEA stated that there have been only 30 deaths involving kratom reported and confirmed. They were usually cases involving coingestants, such as very strong drugs (fentanyl, an opioid many times more potent than heroin, was one). It cannot be assumed that kratom was to blame for the deaths when such powerful substances were involved as well. 88,000 deaths a year are attributed to alcohol (according to Centers for Disease Control and Prevention government website, http://www.cdc.gov/alcohol/fact-sheets/alcohol-use.htm ), and NSAID's such as ibuprofen and aspirin are blamed for 16,500 deaths per year (according to a study published in the American Journal of Therapeutics and an FDA article, http://www.fda.gov/ohrms/dockets/ac/02/briefing/3882B2_02_McNeil-NSAID.htm#_Toc18761784 ), all in the US alone. The numbers for deaths involving kratom (not necessarily caused by it) are miniscule in comparison and hardly warrant a drastic action like scheduling kratom. 
There are articles in scientific journals about kratom. Megan Rech, a clinical pharmacologist, pointed out in a 2014 article that serious toxicity from kratom is rare and usually involves relatively high doses or coingestants. The article can be found by following this link -  onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/phar.1522/full . A 2015 literature review in the International Journal of Legal Medicine gave a similar assessment of kratom. Marcus Warner, a Florida forensic scientists, wrote that "kratom is considered minimally toxic". Link for the review - link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00414-015-1279-y . A program officer for an international health promotion organization called PSI, Pascal Tanguay of Thailand, stated in a 2013 interview that "there's never been a single death associated with kratom. People have been chewing this for thousands of years with no cases of overdose, psychosis, murder, violent crime. Never in all of recorded history." Link - https://www.minnpost.com/global-post/2013/09/thailand-s-cure-meth-addiction-leafy-jungle-stimulant . There are many other expert opinions widely available online that echo such statements.
I know I'm not the only one who finds kratom to be helpful in my life, many Americans feel the same way. More than 100,000 Americans signed the White House petition that opposed the scheduling of kratom, which I didn't find surprising, seeing that I've met many upstanding, good citizens online who feel that kratom helps with their issues. Among those who use kratom, there are brave veterans who served our country, loving mothers, hard working blue collar laborers and many other varying groups.  It would negatively impact many Americans if kratom was banned as a schedule 1 substance, because we would lose access to an herb that we personally feel assists us with our issues. I strongly believe that kratom should not be scheduled at all, but rather be treated like other helpful herbal supplements (such as St John's Wort, ginseng, valerian root and others). It is a helpful herb that, experts agree, is not significantly more dangerous than the herbal supplements I mentioned above, so it should not be treated with stricter rules than them. This would allow kratom to stay available to people who find it helpful in their lives. Please help thousands of wonderful American people by not scheduling kratom.

Good day, my name is Michael B, and I am a 33 year old ASCP laboratory scientist residing in Washington State. After the sudden unexpected passing of my father in 2011, I found myself spiraling uncontrollably down to rock bottom.  I had always been able to handle the light instances of depression and social anxiety I experienced through my life, but this life altering event exponentially exacerbated my symptoms.  I lost a promising job opportunity due to the ingestion of illicit substances, which in turn contributed towards the premature finale of a long term relationship I was in at the time. I have repaired relationships with my family and friends that were damaged through my unhealthy lifestyle, and now look forward to each new day.  Kratom has helped me achieve all these things.

You will have the respect of the citizenry, and can take an important, necessary step towards impactful drug reform in this country.  Thank you so much for you time and this opportunity to tell my story.  

Sincerely,
Michael B.

I know this is off topic but you should definitely read this article:
Marijuana Legalization in CO, WA, AK, OR, and Washington D.C.: So Far, So Good




October 13, 2016 - By Joy Haviland 
 





As Arizona, California, Maine, Massachusetts, and Nevada prepare to vote on the legalization of marijuana for adults 21 and over in a few weeks, all eyes are on the initial outcomes of those states that have already legalized marijuana. A new report from the Drug Policy Alliance finds a massive drop in marijuana arrests, no increase in youth marijuana use, no increase in traffic fatalities, and major fiscal benefits in states with legalized marijuana.

In 2012, Colorado and Washington became the first two U.S. states - and the first two jurisdictions in the world - to approve ending marijuana prohibition and legally regulating marijuana production, distribution and sales. In 2014, Alaska and Oregon followed suit, while Washington D.C. passed a more limited measure that legalized possession and home cultivation of marijuana (but did not address its taxation and sale due to D.C. law).

Despite decades of prohibition and aggressive enforcement, marijuana remains widely consumed and universally available. Marijuana prohibition has been a costly failure - to individuals, communities, and the entire country. A marijuana arrest creates a permanent criminal record that can easily be found by employers, landlords, schools, credit agencies and banks and operates as a significant obstacle in daily life. The huge number of marijuana arrests every year usurps scarce law enforcement, criminal justice and treatment resources at enormous cost to taxpayers.

As public attitudes toward marijuana have changed, some states have sought to pave a new way forward. And preliminary data from those states bring good news.

The new report reveals that statewide surveys of youth in Colorado, Washington, Alaska, and Oregon found that there were no significant increases in youth marijuana use post-legalization. Tax revenues in Colorado, Washington, and Oregon have all exceeded initial revenue estimates, totaling half a billion dollars in new revenue for those states. (Retail sales have not yet begun in Alaska.) Legalization has not led to more dangerous road conditions, as traffic fatality rates have remained stable in Colorado, Washington, Alaska, and Oregon.

Arrests in all states and Washington, D.C. have plummeted since legalization, saving those jurisdictions millions of dollars and preventing the criminalization of thousands of people. Legalization, however, did not abate the disproportionate enforcement of marijuana laws against black people. While thousands less are being arrested, blacks are still arrested at vastly disproportionate rates, even though white people use and sell marijuana at similar rates.

By shifting away from counterproductive marijuana arrests and focusing instead on public health, states that have legalized marijuana are diminishing many of the worst harms of the war on drugs, while managing to raise substantial new revenue for their state.

Joy Haviland is a staff attorney for marijuana law and policy at the Drug Policy Alliance.
Thank you,
Howard Alexander Stafford

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern:

I understand, honor and respect the goal of the DEA in reducing the harm that drugs can have on our society. In the world that we live in, there are innumerable drugs that can cause irreparable harm to any member of our country - and are especially dangerous to a certain portion of our citizens. I am 26, but the better part of my adolescence was spent visiting my brothers in rehabilitation clinics for opiate addiction, driving them to and from family visits and doing whatever I could to help them get off drugs. However, like many others, only one of my brothers made it out of his addiction alive. At the age of 19, I lost the most important person in my life at the time, my beloved brother Michael Cappello of an overdose. The many years I spent helping him ended in a half hour attempting to perform CPR on his cold, lifeless body. I mention this because I want it to be understood that I can personally relate to the worst consequences that illicit substances can cause. 

While the most frequently, and often most effective, way that the DEA can protect the citizens of our country from illicit substances is through physical seizure, there is another extremely important route as well: through truthful and effective education. While the DEA cannot(and should not) regulate substances through popular vote, it is absolutely essential to the goals of the DEA, and ultimately the safety of the public, that the information and actions that the DEA is responsible for are scientifically accurate. When the DEA makes decisions that are not scientifically honest and accurate, it does itself and it's citizens a severe disservice by slowly eroding the trust that the public has for the DEA. The public perception (and trust of) the DEA is directly linked to how serious it's citizens take it's warning about illicit substances. 

As a healthcare professional who has used kratom, I can say, along with thousands of others, that kratom does not pose any 'imminent' threat to the public. In order to maintain the best relationship with the public, the DEA should side with science that we have available, and withdraw it's intent to ban kratom completely. This decision is best for the liberty, helps multitudes of people that are use the supplement to improve their quality of life, and helps maintain a positive public perception of the DEA.

The action to schedule kratom by the DEA is a mistake. Simply put, kratom is a benign substance. It is a completely safe and natural plant that has provided not only myself, but innumerable others with a better quality of life. Additionally, kratom is not an addictive substance or one that is in any way a risk to public safety. If the DEA continues with their plan to schedule kratom, it will not only erode trust and relations between citizens and the DEA, but will detrimentally effect thousands of law-abiding, contributing members of our society. 
    I began supplementing with kratom two years ago. I had overcome one the most difficult times in my life - - a drug addiction. In treatment, I was prescribed an opiate maintenance drug known as Suboxone. I had taken Suboxone for around a year, but there were many side effects which hindered my quality of life and ability to perform day to day functions. As an opiate, Suboxone also carried with it the risk of overdose through respiratory depression and potential for abuse, along with being equally as physically addictive as other opiates. Not long after, I did not want to be on Suboxone. I wanted to live a normal life; however,I found that getting clean from my prescribed opiate maintenance drug was even harder to quit than my original drug of choice. I didn't want to be on Suboxone anymore though, so I did some research and found a natural supplement called kratom. Kratom was a miracle for me. It allowed me to get off of Suboxone without having to miss work. I found that I could lead a normal and productive life with the help of kratom, with no risk of harm to my health and no risk of addiction. Without kratom, my life would in a much worse place. I finally finished up my bachelor's degree, am looking into graduate school for a doctorate, and have a great job bartending and managing a restaurant. 
     I understand that the DEA's ultimate goal is to help protect US citizens. It's a difficult and admirable job; however their efforts to schedule kratom are misguided. Kratom is a wonderful alternative to potentially harmful substances, and have provided countless people with a new lease on life. This scheduling effort represents an unprecedented overreach of the DEA and the federal government, and following through will damage relations among the DEA and the general public. Together, we can prevent immeasurable hardship on thousands of people by allowing kratom to remain legal. We can mend and strengthen relations between the general public and government agencies like the DEA if we listen to common sense, scientific/empirically backed data, and public sentiment. Ignoring those key factors in an effort to overregulate will only hurt law abiding citizens in the Kratom community and further tarnish public perception of the DEA. it's time for the DEA to focus its efforts on the actual dangerous substances and leave Kratom alone. Thank you for your time and consideration.

documents.commentText: My opinion is that these substances should not be placed into Schedule I at this time. The plant kratom (whose primary psychoactive components are mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine) has long been used as a staple of traditional medicine in Southeast Asia; it has also been used safely by millions of people in the U.S., and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement. Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, as the side effects and withdrawal symptoms of kratom are much milder than those of opioids. Placing mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine into Schedule I would remove this avenue of opioid relief, thereby worsening the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose, as well as furthering an overzealous war on drugs that is increasingly ineffective, unpopular, and disproportionately targeted towards low-income communities and people of color. Furthermore, placing these substances into Schedule I would also halt promising scientific studies that seek to codify kratom's potential use as an opioid treatment. While there are some legitimate concerns regarding the adverse effects of kratom abuse, and there is a definite need for kratom to be regulated in some manner, I believe that placing mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine into Schedule I is an overreaction that will ultimately create more problems than it solves.

documents.commentText:
As of this date, I am not currently a user of, nor have I ever taken Kratom. I do not own any stake or profit from any form of Kratom or its distribution. I am not a doctor, nor am I involved in any form of medicine. I am a 34 year old Corporate Safety director for a construction company. I have done my own research and sought many sources to make an educated decision on whether or not Kratom should become a schedule 1 drug. My comments will focus on the medicinal/dietary supplement purpose and not the recreational use. 

Medicinal Purpose:
The potential medical benefits of Kratom and other substances like it warrant further investigation and testing. From what I have read, in many cases it is used as a non-synthesized alternative medicine for daily pain management. Some references I have seen made to treatment are for a range of skin disorders, arthritis, after injury care, depression, anxiety and an alternative to alleviate the withdrawal symptoms of opiate addiction instead of methadone. These are just a few of the many I have read about.

Potential of Abuse:
As an opioid and psychoactive stimulant, there may be physical and mental addiction possibilities. Also, distilling or extracting the components of it may be a source of abuse. Cases of death that i have read about typically involve mixing either legal/non-legal drugs, prescription medications or alcohol and in my opinion decrease the validity of actual causation of death. Without research this is left open for interpretation.

Addiction:
In my research I have heard many people say there is no chance of addiction or any ill side effects. I believe to say that is irresponsible without the appropriate unbiased 3rd party testing. 

In my opinion, there are not enough legitimately documented cases of sickness, hospitalization or death to properly classify it as a public danger, with no medicinal value. Doing so before proper testing is done and removing it from the average public consumer is irresponsible and counter-productive. Premature scheduling limits availability for large scale testing, and a negative connotation is associated potentially without cause.

Like many substances criminalized in the public, media and in schools (i.e "Reefer Madness"), instead of regulation and eliminating personal choice, discussion should be around education and moderation.

I will own that my references are specifically biased toward the benefit of continued public consumption and availability of Kratom, as the detracting statements I have read are largely from businesses that will indirectly profit from it becoming a scheduled drug, and media outlets that are publicizing it for ratings.

I am formally stating that I believe that the testimonial results of benefits I have watched, read and heard, and small testing scenarios that are published about the benefits, the lack of large quantifiable detractors who are actual users who have suffered negative consequences, and the currently under researched potential have successfully persuaded me to request that this NOT become a scheduled drug.

documents.commentText:
I do not wish to make the pharmacological or statistical argument for Kratom, because the American Kratom Association is gathering information and conducting statistical research at this very moment. I stand behind their statements made so far, and I trust in their ability to provide overwhelming evidence on the side of kratom's continued legality. 

Instead, I will give a personal view on the subject. To make a long story short: I used to be a fuck-up, as recently as 8-10 months ago. I was unmotivated, unsuccessful in both (university) academic and professional settings, and barely managed to get out of bed most days. I wasn't addicted to drugs, exactly--but I used them all the time, and I lost sight of my responsibilities, I lost sight of my friends and family. I was caught in a vicious, self-destructive loop of generalized depression, and I didn't see a way out. One day I read about kratom on the internet, and noticed that an increased sense of well-being was one of the main effects. Desperate for an answer, searching for a supplement that could help me climb out of suicidal ideation and self-inflicted misery, I ordered kratom from the internet.

The first time I consumed kratom, I took WAY too much. Approximately 35 grams. I didn't have a scale, and I mixed many large scoops of kratom into a cup of cold water. For context, the average kratom dose is between 2-8 grams. As you can imagine, the results were not pleasant. about 5 minutes later I threw up, and I was sleepy with a headache for the next 6-7 hours. I sobered up, however, and woke up the next day with no hangover. 

I mean for that anecdote to show just how safe kratom is. I took SEVEN TIMES the recommended kratom dosage. I had no lasting negative effects, and simply threw up. It was less severe than a hangover from a normal night of drinking vodka. Can you imagine if I took SEVEN TIMES the recommended dosage of Oxycontin, or SEVEN TIMES the dosage of heroin? I have a friend who nearly passed away from an opioid overdose this year, as he lost the ability to breathe (respiratory depression, which kratom cannot induce) from Oxycontin. This happened even though his dosage was only twice that of his normal amount. If it weren't for the hardworking emergency responders we are blessed to have in this country, I would have lost him. 

The second time I took kratom, a few days later, I took 6 grams. I noticed an increased sense of well-being, a little pain relief, and a small boost in mental energy. It felt similar to coffee, although coffee makes me jittery and nervous, and hurts my stomach terribly. I noticed right away that kratom wasn't like other substances, as after I felt the effects I immediately wanted to do my homework. I completed it for the first time in months, and then I cleaned my room. I then called my mother, and spoke to her for half an hour. There was no noticeable comedown from the effects of kratom, and in fact as the effects wore off I merely grew slightly tired, as if caffeine was leaving my body. 

I take 5 grams of kratom every single day, and I have for six months now. I use it as a supplement at the end of the day to improve my mood, and boost my focus on household tasks and late-night work. I want to make it clear that kratom does not run my life. I have quit for 2 weeks on two separate occasions, and experienced no significant physical or mental withdrawals. 

I have turned my life around in more ways than one. I am in a committed and healthy monogamous relationship, I get along well with my parents, and my career is finally trending upwards. Did I do all of this because of kratom? Of course not--I improved my life on my own. But the presence of kratom in my life has been wholly positive, providing someone prone to bouts of depression with a subtle motivator and mood enhancement. 

I am a hardworking graduate student. I am a thoughful dog owner. I am a kind boyfriend. I am a proud voter. I am a tax-payer, and I am a patriotic citizen. If the DEA is successful in banning kratom, they will have added to the list. I never wish to say: "I am a Felon." Please do not criminalize a nearly harmless substance that has allowed me to change my life for the better. I make no angry demands--instead I make an honest plea. Allow me to carry on with my art and my productivity and my kratom, a leaf that has been consumed in Southeastern Asia for thousands of years. Allow me to live as I have been living. Please don't pull the carpet out from under my feet. Please.

documents.commentText:
Kratom has been a godsend to me since I discovered it a few years ago. I've had to deal with anxiety all of my life and have been put on every type of anti-depressant to try and alleviate what I have suffered for so long. Nothing quite seemed to work and the side effects of some of these medications were unbearable. Try titrating off Effexor while going to work and simply performing the necessities of life, I've never felt worse. 

I finally got my anxiety somewhat under control with Citalopram and Xanax but as a result I was emotionally and mentally flatlined. It was not a life at all. I was just a shell of a person with zero desires as a result. This situation unto itself lead to depression and all that comes with it. I had IBS, my thoughts were that of a nihilist who was just hung up on life as a whole. The thought of living this way for the rest of my life consumed every minute of my life. Something had to change. 

I came across Kratom from a military vet that I met at our local dog park. He used it for pain and he also alluded to it helping with what I assume was PTSD. He didn't really want to relive his past and how he got to using Kratom but he was pretty emphatic on how Kratom had helped him.

I sort of brushed it off but said I would give it a try. The following day he gave me a little bit and I told him I would try it. I took the pills that he had given me and about 30 minutes later I felt the effects. My inner dialogue that was always so negative seemed to have quieted for the moment. That alone was a relief. If anyone here has anxiety or depression you know what your inner dialogue / voice can do to you mentally. 

What Kratom did was essentially alleviate all my negative thoughts for the moment. And within that moment I felt like my head was cleared and I felt optimistic. It wasn't euphoria, it was finally just a different mindset that none of the medication I had been on ever offered. At that moment I just cried, I felt something different which hadn't happened in a long time. I was just so happy to feel something other than my flatline self. 

Since that day I have been using Kratom every other day. I got off all my other meds over the course of two months and that alone should be a reason for Kratom to be legal. I know it helps people with opiod withdrawal but I'm here to state that it helps with the ever-so-cumbersome withdrawal from anti-depressants and controlled substances like Xanax. 

That is essentially my story and how Kratom has given me life again in some respect. My anxiety isn't completely gone by any means, but I'm managing it in a different and natural way. I gained 15 pounds while on anti-depressants and that is gone as well. Depression can also lead to IBS which I had and as a side benefit Kratom helped me with that affliction as well. 

To ban Kratom is to hand some users back to the medicines that didn't work or made them feel "better" by completely blunting our emotions and personality. That is a road I never wish to go down again. The fact of the matter is that I have an imbalance that is anxiety for whatever reason. This is how I'm wired and it is something I have to deal with for the rest of my life. I didn't choose to have anxiety. I wish I was a med-free functioning soul but it has never been in the cards for me. I've been afflicted with anxiety since I can remember a child. 

I should be able to use Kratom as I have so that I do not have to go back to what I was on. This should be my choice and my choice only. Please do not take this option away from me and hand me back to the mental health industry that has given me the million dollar work up only to let me down. I can't go back to such a life.

My name is Jeremy Cranfill, I'm a 40-year old male who is a foster caregiver for adults with developmental disabilities. 

I'd like to voice my opposition to the DEAs Intent to Schedule the alkaloids Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, which would make Kratom (Mitragynaspeciosa), a schedule 1 controlled substance. This would put kratom, an herbal supplement helping millions of people suffering chronic and acute mental and physical conditions that is also safely easing the nation's opiate epidemic problem naturally, on the same level as illegal drugs like heroin. It would also prevent further research which, to date, has shown kratom to be an effective painkiller that does not cause respiratory depression; the main cause of death from opiate overdose.

I first discovered kratom about 15 years ago when I was looking for a natural anxiolytic and relaxant to help me improve my quality of life while dealing with chronic anxiety and depression.  I found this plant to be up to the task and began using it on an occasional basis prepared as a tea.  I found it to be a gentle relaxant with no obvious side-effects.  Around 2005 I incurred a severe spinal injury which resulted in severe chronic pain in my lower back and legs. In 2006 I had a 2-level spinal fusion which alleviated some of the pain, but also caused additional chronic pain my lower back and hips.  Since that time I have suffered from incurable chronic nerve and musculoskeletal pain and have been on prescription opiate therapy ever since.  

While the opiates have been a blessing, they are also a curse as the Tylenol that comes with them is taking a toll on my liver.  About 3 years ago I made the choice to begin using kratom to improve my quality of life while dealing with chronic pain and to reduce the opiates needed to control it.  To my surprise I found that kratom greatly improved my quality of life and helped me rely less upon the opiates, so I gradually made the switch and I have now been free of prescription opiate drugs entirely for the past 2 1/2 years.

For me this plant is a miracle and it would negatively impact my quality of life if I had to switch back to prescription drugs due to a ban on this beneficial herb.  In my long relationship with this plant, I have never found it addictive or harmful in any way.  Please study this plant further and understand what a wonderful herbal supplement it can be.

I ask you to please oppose any outright ban or any moves to schedule this plant or its constituent parts.

I am a long time sufferer of anxiety. I have self-medicated before with other substances, but all others had negative effects that were not worth the benefits. However, with kratom I've found that a few grams in a tea every morning and afternoon drastically reduces my anxiety with virtually no negative effects. 

The effects I notice can be described as a strong cup of coffee that gives me energy without making me jittery, and a slight sense of well-being without any real disturbances to my thought process. I can perfectly function at home and at work-- actually it improves my productivity in many cases-- and once the effects start to fade I feel quite normal again without any dip in mood or energy. 

I have never used it for treating opioid addiction, but have read many anecdotal accounts of kratom playing a crucial role in weaning one off more dangerous opiates such prescription painkillers as codeine, fentanyl, and hydrocodone, and street drugs like heroin. I believe that placing mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine into Schedule I would simply be fueling the prescription painkiller addiction epidemic that this country is currently experiencing, and possibly supporting the pharmaceutical companies that may have interest in these chemicals. 

I could not believe my eyes when I saw the patent on these active alkaloids, "Methods For Treating Withdrawal From Addictive Compounds" (patent number: US 20100209542 A1), yet still somehow the DEA wishes to place them into a category for chemicals with no accepted medical use. The hypocrisy is unbelievable and I can only begin to speculate that this discrepancy has come from a lack of communication rather than any profit-motivated interests on the part of any types of pharmaceutical corporations.

For the reasons I've stated above, I sincerely hope that kratom will remain a legal, freely-available supplement that will continue to benefit millions of Americans every day. However, I also believe that some system of regulation to ensure quality and potency, as with any substance for human consumption, would be beneficial in furthering the usefulness of this amazing plant and its compounds. Thanks for your time.

documents.commentText: As a healthcare professional, I believe that Kratom is a safer alternative to opiates and opioids and an invaluable tool in treating and controlling opiate or opioid addiction. I have very much first-hand experience with patients that have gained great health benefits from it because it allowed them to transition smoothly and safely away from harder drugs. Whole kratom is, as an addictive substance, quite self-limiting in that the user will have a very difficult time building a substantial tolerance/dependence. After a certain dose threshold, the drug becomes a very unpleasant experience, with signs and symptoms including nausea, emesis, epigastric pain, and dysphoria. I have seen many patients chase a high and be bitten harmlessly by the side effects of the drug. Simply put, this is a substance that has "built-in" safeguards against not only tolerance building, but overdose. My personal recommendation would be to list purified/extracted solutions of 7-hydroxymitragynine and mitragynine as schedule one and/or any product containing stronger than specific thresholds of the psychoactive constituents (i.e. a concentration that clearly indicates a refined product). But please do not schedule the plant. Thank you for taking the time to consider my statement.

Docket No. DEA-442W

On behalf of the millions of Americans using Kratom responsibly every day, people who work hard and pay taxes and feed their families, I urge you to completely reverse course on the decision to schedule Mitragyna Speciosa. 

It appears that the DEA was attempting to act on bad intel. Its recent decision to delay the scheduling and allow comment is indicative of this, as I am positive that the DEA would not have done this had they felt the info that was the basis of these actions was objectively credible. I look to the emergency scheduling of synthetic substances with high potential for abuse, such as MDMA or "Bath Salts" as perfectly credible and effective uses of emergency scheduling based on credible, actionable information. With substances like "spice" and "flocka" hitting the streets, I am sympathetic to the DEA's urge to protect the American public from harm, but I firmly believe that this proposal to schedule Kratom is hasty and would ultimately do more harm to the public than good. 

Kratom has not been responsible for a death without a catalyst or contraindication - deaths which the media has associated with Kratom have mostly if not entirely turned out to have other substances, and/or complicated health issues involved. Kratom's footprint on the workload of our Poison Control center is absolutely infinitesimal when compared to benign foodstuffs and everyday cleaning products. The increase in recent calls is objectively attributable to its recent gain in popularity coupled with product ignorance and inquiry from general practitioners. Kratom's activity on opioid receptors is unique in its minimalism and the near impossibility of respiratory arrest, according to recent study by Columbia University. 

As more scientific study is conducted on this plant, the lack of evidence of danger/toxcicity becomes more apparent as we continue to lack sufficient reason to believe this plant is anything more than mildly addictive. If we are to ban plants on the basis of mild addictive potential, I suppose we should do away with coffee and tobacco. If we are to ban plants based on mild opioid activity, I suppose we should look at Spinach next. 

One thing is clear - there are hundreds of thousands, (considering the significant percentage of the botanical trade Kratom is responsible for) if not millions of Americans using Kratom every single day without incident. Thousands of families living happily with Kratom users among them. Because Kratom is legal, it is bought and sold safely and not under the control of gangs or cartels. Frankly, Kratom is so mild that it would be an absolute failure as an illicit substance. 

Many Kratom users are astute and have observed that medicines based on Mitragyna alkaloid content have been patented - we see this as a potential collusion between the FDA and Pharmaceutical Lobbyists who see the therapeutic potential of this plant and wish to make maximum profit from it. If the DEA is truly concerned with the well being of the American people, it will do everything it can to work with the FDA and ensure that Kratom remains legal and regulated like any other dietary supplement, subject to the same safety and cleanliness standards, and available to America.

Thank you for your time.

- over 88,000 deaths directly attributable to alcohol 
- over 28,000 deaths directly attributable to Opioids, with half of those (~14,000) being prescriptions related

documents.commentText:
I apologize for writing anonymously, but I feel, given the uncertain circumstances, that I should do so to protect myself and my family. I am a 70 year old male, married to the same woman for almost 50 years, blessed with two children and three grandchildren. I am now retired from the computer programming profession. In the past 5 years, I have had two spinal fusion surgeries, and now have seven fused vertebrae in my lumbar region. Three years ago, I was diagnosed as needing a right knee replacement, which I hope to have done in January of 2017. After reviewing the evidence -- x-ray, MRI, and formal medical diagnosis -- no physician has ever questioned my assertion that I am in pain and discomfort with most every step I take -- sometimes bearable, sometimes not. I think the surgeries have prevented my symptoms from getting steadily and progressively even worse, but they have not eliminated the pain and discomfort by any means. I have tried the usual recommended therapies; they run the gamut from physical therapy, to bed rest, heat, cold, OTC medications, and prescription medications. I do not tolerate opiates well, even though, of the therapies mentioned above, they are the most effective for reducing pain. I also do not like the cognitive clouding that accompanies their use.

After my second back operation, a little over a year ago, an acquaintance suggested that I might find relief with the alkaloid mitragynine, a component of an herb commercially available as "kratom". I tried it with skepticism, because I am not a huge believer in herbal therapies, but to my surprise, it has reasonably effective analgesic qualities without the cognitive side effects. I can make use of it on those "bad" days, and ignore it on better days. I have not, to date, experienced any withdrawal effects such as those accompanying opiates. In short, it helps prevent my quality of life from deteriorating further, or at least slows its progression. I am aware of my own responsibilities in dealing with pain, and do not expect magic effects from any substance or therapeutic procedure. If I have tried everything to reduce pain on a given day, without success, I know that more of the same is not going to help and it's time to grit my teeth and try to endure.

I am opposed to the re-classification of mitragynine/kratom for two main reasons. The first is the personal quality-of-life issue which I've tried to describe above. The second reason is based on what I know about human nature: individuals who are in frequent and unrelenting pain will try almost anything, and search almost anywhere, for relief. Unfortunately, in this case, most of the alternatives are ineffective, or dangerous, or highly controlled and illegal. Prohibiting the use of mitragynine would force those who find it useful into searching for and trying other unknown and/or dangerous forms of relief, or promised relief. Re-classifying this substance at this time, without further controlled, scientific study by trained and independent parties will only harm individuals such as myself in ways that may not be anticipated.

Thank you for considering my opinion and the opinions of all those who will be affected by your decision.

I am a Biochemistry teacher and not a kratom user, although I do know of others who do. Please take more care in researching the peer-reviewed literature on kratom and it's alkaloids. The lethal dose of kratom alkaloids in mice was so high that it could not be determined in a peer-reviewed study. This strongly indicates that the potential for overdosage is vanishingly small. If you look at the mechanism of action of the main alkaloids, the literature strongly suggests they selectively act in a biochemical pathway that does not cause respiratory depression ( almost always the cause of opiate death) or cause the down-regulation of opiate receptors ( a main cause of opiate dependence). Studies and anecdotal evidence indicate that any dependence from long-term use is less than that of codeine, a drug sold over the counter in many places without issue. There is mounting evidence that kratom alkaloids act in an agonist-antagonist fashion. Sort of like a very weak suboxone. Using large doses of these alkaloids appears to inhibit their own action; There are no reports (that I have seen) of people abusing  large amounts to get a morphine-like or cocaine-like "high". I have only seen one report in the peer-reviewed literature of what appeared to be a fatal kratom overdose. In this case there were also other drugs in the patients system and no way to determine if other indeterminate factors were the actual cause of death. It would appear, in any case, that the percent mortality of kratom users is far less than that of acetaminophen or ibuprofen users.

I am doing so in the hopes that testimonies like mine may help to educate, unravel stigma and ultimately help prevent an unnecessary and potentially tragic scheduling of this herbal supplement which is in many regards comparable to coffee, yerba mate, or loose leaf tea. 

I began utilizing the benefits of powdered kratom leaf in 2011 after suffering from severe lower back pain, moderate depression and social anxiety as well as bouts of gastrointestinal distress.  Seeking relief for lower back pain in particular, I decided to try kratom and after just a few instances of using it and titrating for an effective dose, I found that it was simultaneously the most effective, and least debilitating pain relief I had ever experienced! Instead of feeling drowsy and unable to perform energetic or complex tasks like the prescription opiates I had tried before would make me feel, I found that kratom would actually boost my motivation and ability to get things done, while also providing enough pain relief to maintain a positive mood and enjoy being social. 

I continued taking kratom on an almost daily basis which made it possible for me to maintain a strenuous job as an arborist over the next two summers and to finish my Bachelor's degree in Ecological Design during the school year. Interestingly, and somewhat unexpectedly, I found that my dosage was steadily decreasing over this time, especially as my back pain subsided and my use of kratom became much more equivalent to how one might drink coffee or tea for productive stimulation. 

More recently I have been relying on kratom for the painful, disruptive, embarrassing, and energy draining symptoms of IBS-D (Irritable Bowel Syndrome  Diarrhea) as well as the co-morbid depression and anxiety. Preventing the research of mitragyna speciosa by placing it's two of many active alkaloid constituents: mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine into a Schedule 1 category, would be a grave mistake for the medical and pharmaceutical industries and the American people who could benefit so greatly from this complex yet gentle medicine. I urge anyone reading this to carefully consider what power they have and how to best use it for the prevention of unnecessary suffering. Please consider the mounting evidence regarding kratom, both peer-reviewed and anecdotal, carefully and compassionately. A great many people's health, jobs, families and futures depend on the availability of this plant.

"Michael Friedman, Paul Goldenheim and Howard Udell, three pharmaceutical executives who previously worked on OxyContin, are likely regretting their criminal plea agreement that led to a 12-year ban on doing business with Medicare and Medicaid...The men [eventually] pled guilty to falsely marketing OxyContin as being less addictive than other painkillers. They were accused of releasing erroneous data related to clinical trials and burying the relatively dramatic fall-off in blood levels by using a different type of data table than the majority of us are used to reading." The DEA should be all the more familiar with the story of Tramadol.

Instead, the agency recommended not putting tramadol under the Controlled Substance Act. Restrictions on prescribing it are no more stringent than for Lipitor or Viagra.

"The Controlled Substance Act places drugs into five progressively restrictive categories based on their abuse potential. At the top of the list are drugs such as heroin. At the other, are some cough medicines with limited amounts of codeine.

"In approving tramadol, the FDA decision was based largely on research in which the drug was injected. The FDA also weighed evidence from Europe, where tramadol had been on the market for years.

"But the FDA also had research showing that when given to opioid abusers orally in high doses, rather than being injected, it produced opiate-like effects that were similar to oxycodone, the narcotic in OxyContin, one of the most abused drugs in America.

DEA, you may listen to us or pharmaceutical lobbyists. We will await, and widely disseminate, the proof of your purpose.

In 2013 I was diagnosed with vaginal in situ carcinoma.  In terms of invasive cancer, it is minor and easily removed through local excision.  However, the pain inflicted during this delicate operation was beyond what I had ever experienced.  First, this should not be an outpatient procedure.  Due to the large amount nerve bundles in the area, this surgery felt like I was filleted open and left to deal with it at home only a few hours later.  I was given Vicodin...a lot of Vicodin.  100 pills to be exact.  The fact that I was given so much is testament to the degree of pain everyone knew I would be in.  And, I took them.  I took them all.  
Now, I had taken pain killers before, but only small amounts for high acuity conditions where long term pain is not expected.  Removal of wisdom teeth, a fractured ankle bone.  This is manageable and I had no issue with addiction in these cases.  This surgery was re markedly different and at the end of 100 pills, I was not only physically addicted but also mentally.  
After seeing my physician, he noted that a course of Tramadol would help.  Worse mistake ever.  Tramadol has been known to induce SSRI components and for a person that was already depressed due to the nature of the surgery just endured, this exacerbated my addiction and ultimately led to drug seeking behavior.  As a successful professional and dedicated wife and mother, how did I get here.  It was unbearably shameful and debilitating in every way.
After a year of drug seeking to now fill the void of addiction and depression, I needed some way out.  I had tried tapering tramadol to no avail.  When I decreased to the smallest amount possible, my depression kicked in full gear and consumed me.  We added anti-depressants one right after another that illicit more side effects and no relief.  This, I thought, was my lot in life now.  My never ending penance to pay for an addiction.
Then, for some reason I can't remember now, I saw an article on kratom and its uses to help opiate addiction.  I investigated further only to find a few reputable studies that tried to illuminate the nature of its use, both historically and in modern society as well as future benefits.  With not much to lose, I tried it.  At first in very small doses where I also kept a diary detailing any side effects, both good and bad.  (Note:  I am a biologist) I stopped Tramadol for a full 48 hours before I took a dose kratom to ensure no interaction and also limited caffeine and any OTC medications.  After one week of only kratom use, I felt 80% normal.  After 2 weeks, 95% of my life was returned to me.  I had only minor nausea that was easily limited by modifying the dose (reduction).  After finding my optimal dose to achieve normality, I did not dose further.
Conclusion:  This plant helped ME kick a very serious and potentially life threatening addiction.  I dose now only occasionally, having completed a titration off kratom for months at a time.  Now, it's used only to facilitate focus when needed for a deadline at work.  I find is also helps relieve my anxiety that we all deal with day to day.  Avenues for regulation of kratom moving forward:  Get kratom out of head shops.  Preferably, this should be sold only by pharmacies that can track and regulate its use.  Keep it OTC, but require a pharmacy consult before hand.  The reason kratom works so well for opiate addicts is because its OTC.  The shame felt by many addicts is the primary obstacle toward their sobriety.  Keeping it accessible is key to that success.  Finally, making something illegal doesn't do anything to address the problem of why its needed in the first place. Taking a stance of increased legality of a product that is clearly helping more people than it hurts will only erode any trust people have in the DEA.  The effects of that are already being felt with marijuana across the country.  Please consider the body of evidence (which is neither conclusive nor complete as of yet) before making rash decisions.  Continue to allow use of kratom in the free market and push for funding of comprehensive, randomized/blinded trials to understand its use, implications and place in society.  Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Dear Sir/Madam:

I am a 30 year old attorney from Philadelphia and I am writing to encourage you to refrain from scheduling kratom.  I think everyone agrees that the opioid epidemic is a serious problem in this country, but kratom is a substance that will help battle the opioid epidemic, not contribute to it.  Kratom has been used for hundreds of years as a safe alternative to overcome serious opioid addictions in Southeast Asia.  Kratom is a much safer alternative to dangerous opioids like Percocet and/or Vicodin that are ROUTINELY prescribed by doctors, not to mention the serious killers like heroin and fentanyl.  There has yet to be a single reported mono-drug overdose death attributed to kratom in the USA, meanwhile, over-the-counter painkillers like Tylenol and Advil kill hundreds every year.  I have been using kratom daily for chronic pain and depression/anxiety for several months now and the worst side effect I ever had was nausea-- once.  I have also found that kratom's effects "plateau" at a point, meaning that it is much less likely to be abused that other drugs that "compound" their effects with higher doses.  I understand that there needs to be reasonable regulation of kratom (to make sure that it is labeled properly and comes with appropriate warnings, to make sure that the substance is pure, that it is taken with doctor's supervision etc.) and I don't think many users would argue with that, but placing kratom into Schedule I is the equivalent of the death penalty.  Thousands of users will have to either get kratom through black market sources (rather than some of the legitimate, reliable vendors around today), or go back to more dangerous opioids.  Additionally, placing kratom into Schedule I would effectively kill off all research opportunities.  EDUCATION and AWARENESS are the most important tools at the DEA's disposal to keep kratom use safe, not an outright ban.  This is an amazing substance that has a lot of potential to do a lot of good for a lot of people, with little to no side effects if used properly.  A ban on kratom will do nothing but INCREASE the opioid problem in America. There is a precedent for a more passive regulation of substances like kratom, and that is CAFFEINE.  Caffeine is a potent psychoactive drug, yet is treated as a "dietary supplement" by the FDA.  People can die far easier from ingesting caffeine powder than kratom powder.  Caffeine is effectively controlled through our social norms surrounding it-- you use it daily, you get it through coffee or tea, and that's that.  Let's control kratom though education, awareness and culture, not guns and handcuffs.  Thank you very much for your time, and I hope and pray that you please take a reasoned approach to the regulation of kratom.  Let's make it safe and help improve people's lives, not leave people out in the cold.
